segments.text: This is Sunday, the 21st of May.
Just now pulling out of the driveway of the house, heading toward Kerrville for a meeting of the Shriner Board, hoping to do some more recollecting of years at A&M.
Since I'm not positive where I quit with the previous tapes, I apologize in advance for any repetition that may occur.
Now I'm going to stop and see if this machine is working.
First, a little more of a retrospective of Mr. Rutter.
Since we did not know of his decline in physical health, almost none of us had paused to stop and evaluate
all that he had accomplished and all that he had meant to the institution.
In addition to the fact that he was not vulnerable to allegations of not being a Texan or an Aggie or not having been in the Corps or anything like this, it seldom occurred to any of us
that another advantage he possessed was the fact that without the years of graduate study, master's thesis, doctoral dissertation, term papers, and all that the rest of us possessed,
He was able to see to the heart of things perhaps more clearly than most academic eggheads would have been able to view.
He was a true leader, able to make decisions
rather clearly and certainly he stood strongly for everything in which he had a belief and confidence.
I'm convinced that his initial hesitation dash
and possibly even opposition, Dash, to the traumatic changes of the early 60s, coeducation, voluntary Corps of Cadets, racial integration, and general...
academic changes including admission requirements plus curriculum breadth and depth.
That his hesitancy on those
came from his concern over whether or not he could succeed in that campaign.
Thus the former field commander as he looked at the battle plan at first it now seems that he
delayed the attack until he was more positive about the probability of victory for his campaign.
He tended to be a
leader who would personally go to the academic front line, whether it be to Washington, Austin, an A&M board meeting,
session with deans or faculty or a march by the students on his house, he would be there personally to make very clear, usually, that he had made the decision and would stand behind it.
Paragraph, a number of us heard him
identify himself as the Potbellied Prexy which was in part his way of claiming links to A&M's traditions because in his day
the chief executive office, the president, as the chief executive officer was known in the Corps as the Prexy.
In addition, that physical identification was his way of saying, most often with a smile, that he wasn't vain,
nor did he spend much time worrying about whether or not he was clothed in the latest style.
He was in fact ready to do his best
and would take the responsibility for such a venture.
But then he was gone.
The arrival of Dr. Williams
brought some change in style.
He was far more outgoing and was a very skilled speaker.
In those speeches, it seemed to a casual observer
that he was almost speaking extemporaneously.
Now it is obvious that his remarks were carefully planned.
He had a very private
reservoir file of notes, anecdotes, jokes, et cetera, most of which he could deliver flawlessly.
He seemed particularly able
to speak at the level of his audience, whether it be Aggie undergraduates, A&M Mothers Clubs, legislators,
and was particularly skillful at a general meeting of the general faculty.
There he caused almost all of us to walk away saying, this is the man we've been waiting for.
Paragraph once more, his experience at Clemson.
which was far more similar in its background experience to A&M than we realized at the time, helped him to understand very, very well how to relate to
such audiences.
Occasionally, some of us could remember hearing a Williams story for a second time.
For example, the classic account of the man trying to raise the load of bricks
in a pulley system, in which he himself finally got involved, in which the lifter finally got involved, was himself lifted, then dropped, only to be hit on the head by the bricks.
But he was the right man for the time,
Similarly, Mrs. Williams, having been a faculty wife, like being part of an academic couple, like so many of us who had gone through the realities of student housing,

in their years at Emory, then renting an apartment at Clemson, and finally moving to what was for them a very special dream house in a pleasant, quiet, curving, wooded street, timbered street not far from the campus.
Dr. Williams, Dr. and Mrs. Williams had two daughters, thus they were sensitive to the needs of coeds.
Their older daughter, being a college student when they arrived, and their younger
during graduation at A&M Consolidated High School.
Mrs. Williams instantly became very much involved in a broad array of campus activities and seemed more outgoing as a campus first lady than Mrs.
Rudder.
And one of the reasons for that perhaps was because the Rudder children were younger when that administration began in 1959.
And with four youngsters, Mrs.
Rudder
Had more home duties.
Also, she said to many individuals.
That she understood from quote from Earl.
Let my.
Task is to raise the children and keep house.
Period quote.
Many of us assumed, however, that both ladies, Mrs.
Rudder and Mrs. Williams, were quietly influential in their husbands' policies and roles.
Paragraph.
On the first occasion in which my wife and I visited
the new president's home, as we then called it, near the south edge of the campus, I quickly expressed deep impressions with the home's size, beauty,
and style.
Instantly, Mrs. Williams replied by saying, I don't know where you live or what it looks like, but I will swap houses with you instantly with no extra payment.

When I asked her why she felt that way, she pointed out that this was, quote, not my house, period, quote, a comma, quote, and that whatever arrangement she made of furnishings and something else or anything else
that someone offered a comment about how the house had been arranged before the Williams arrived.
Later as campus CEO, later when I became a campus CEO in El Paso and Columbia, Missouri,
My wife and I became far more sensitive to the realities of such changes.
The Williamses had many groups over to the president's home.
And they were always particularly proud
that the first group that came the night they moved in was the Aggie Corps of Cadets led by the A&M band to welcome them with appropriate quote maroon sounding quote tunes to ensure
that they knew they were very deeply appreciated at their new home.
Now this is a note to the typist.
I think I have already dictated a bit about the first conversation with Dr. Williams after he got here.
and also Dr. Calhoun asking me to come over and join him.
Now I want to jump back and talk about teaching at A&M, and we will have to insert this earlier at some point in the tapes chronologically.
Teaching has always been, for me, by far the most satisfying part of academic service.
in using the word quote teaching quote I am including not only the instruction in formal classes but the countless other opportunities for student contact
and always in an office conversation, service on committees and other advisory groups with students, DASH, or any other opportunity for student contact.
paragraph in my opinion teaching is a calling and somehow that idea came into my heart when I and others used to get frustrated at Austin College when we would hear some speaker particularly

at compulsory chapel services on Tuesday and Thursday mornings at 10 o'clock talked to us about, quote, full-time Christian service, quote, dash, which those speakers usually limited to the ordained clergy
This observer, hopefully using what is consistent with the Calvinist beliefs that have run in the family for many generations, is convinced that
every individual may be called to, quote, full-time Christian service, quote, dash, in a truly broad variety of professional tasks.
My inspirations, some of which were realized at the time and some certainly were not, were Faced Range from the third grade, Grace Glaze from the fourth, Myrtmae Force from junior high,
and then Mr. Sidner from Austin College, Elmer Flaccus, and a number of people at Rice.
I never had a formal course from Frank Vandiver, but I certainly
have always felt marked by his splendid and sometimes incredible ability to retain, organize, and share factual information in a meaningful manner.

Another Rice faculty member who was important in my teaching development was Ed Phillips, who one day asked me for advice about whether or not he should accept an Austin College appointment, and I proudly and happily encouraged him to accept it.
He served there for three decades or more and now has been elected an honorary member of one of the rice classes back in the 50s.
Paragraph.
The sum of all of those
the influence from all of those teachers and many others caused me to believe that teaching history at the university level should have as its focus an understanding of
how this great nation came to be what it is and to try to present that information in such a fashion that we might even dream of greater progress in the future.
But while
looking forward, be well aware of the reality that this nation is the world's pacemaker in so many positive ways.
Paragraph.
Every semester,
from the fall of 1959 until our departure from Missouri following the spring semester in 1997, I taught at least one big survey section in US history.
The first years at A&M
There were four sections per semester.
Most of them were History 105, taking the study of the U.S. up through the Civil War.
But some were History 106, the second semester, for the more recent period.
In those courses, I used a lecture outline, which I normally would write on the blackboard prior to the beginning of a lecture.
That meant that I always tried to get to class 10 to 15 minutes before the beginning of that session and put the key points of that lecture on the board.
In addition, I tried to be
particularly careful about names of places, individuals, battles, acts of legislation, et cetera, that the members of the class might not
quickly recognize some sound and or might not be able to spell correctly as we proceeded as the first day of the
of the class arrived, I tried to pass out as quickly as possible a three or four page quote syllabus.
